column2: translit. L’vivs’ka oblast’; also referred to as L’vivshchyna
column3: Ukrainian: Львівщина) is an oblast (province) in western Ukraine. The administrative center of the oblast is the city of Lviv. Population: 2

column1: The oblast was created as part of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic on December 4
column2: 1939 following the Soviet invasion of Poland. The territory of the former Drohobych Oblast was incorporated into the Lviv Oblast in 1959.

column1: The oblast's strategic position at the heart of central Europe and as the gateway to the Carpathians has caused it to change hands many times over the centuries. It was ruled variously by Great Moravia
column4: was independent as the state of Galicia-Volhynia (circa 1200 to 1340)
column5: and then ruled by the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (1340 to 1772)
column7: West Ukrainian People's Republic and Poland (1919 to 1939)
column8: when it was part of the Lwów Voivodeship of the Second Republic of Poland. The region's historically dominant Ukrainian population declared the area to be a part of an independent West Ukrainian National Republic in November 1918 — June 1919
column9: but this endured only briefly. Local autonomy was provided in international treaties but later on those were not honoured by the Polish government and the area experienced much ethnic tension between the Polish and Ukrainian population.

column1: The region and its capital city take their name from the time of Galicia-Volhynia
column4: founded Lviv; naming the city after his son
column6: the general region around Lviv was known as Red Ruthenia (Cherven' Rus').

column1: The region only became part of the Soviet Union under the terms of the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact in 1939
column2: when it was annexed to the Ukrainian SSR. It was occupied by Nazi Germany from 1941 to 1944
column3: when almost all local Jews were killed
column4: and remained in Soviet hands after World War II as was arranged during the Teheran and Yalta conferences. Local Poles were expelled and Ukrainians expelled from Poland arrived. Given its historical development
column5: Lviv Oblast is one of the least Russified and Sovietized parts of Ukraine
column6: with much of its Polish and Habsburg heritage still visible today.

column2: there are three provinces (oblasts) that formed the eastern part of the Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria. Two of these
column3: Lviv Oblast and Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast were entirely contained in the kingdom; the third oblast of Ternopil was mainly in the kingdom apart from four of its most northerly counties (raions). The counties of the Kingdom of Galicia remained largely unchanged when they were incorporated into successor states; with minor changes as detailed below
column4: the current counties are almost co-extensive with those of the Kingdom.

column1: The region is also notable for having declared independence from the central government during the 2014 Euromaidan protests.

The terrain of Lviv Oblast is highly varied. The southern part is occupied by the low Beskyd (ukr: Бескиди) mountain chains running parallel to each other from northwest to southeast and covered with secondary coniferous forests as part of the Eastern Carpathians; the highest point is Pikuy (1408 m). North from there are the wide upper Dniester river valley and much smaller upper San River valley. These rivers have flat bottoms covered with alluvial deposits
column2: and are susceptible to floods. Between these valleys and Beskyd lies the Precarpathian upland covered with deciduous forests
column3: with well-known mineral spa resorts (see Truskavets
column4: Morshyn). It's also the area of one of the earliest industrial petroleum and gas extraction. These deposits are all but depleted by now.

column1: In the central part of the region lie Roztocze
column3: and part of the Podolia uplands. Rich sulphur deposits were mined here during the Soviet era. Roztocze is densely forested
column4: while Opillia and Podolia (being covered with loess on which fertile soils develop) are densely populated and mostly covered by arable land. In the central-north part of the region lies the Small Polesia lowland
column5: geographically isolated from the rest of Polesia but with similar terrain and landscapes (flat plains with sandy fluvioglacial deposits and pine forests). The far North of the region lies on the Volhynia upland
column6: which is also covered with loess; coal is mined in this area.

column1: The climate of Lviv Oblast is moderately cool and humid. The average January temperatures range from −7 °C (19 °F) in the Carpathians to −3 °C (27 °F) in the Dniester and San River valleys while in July the average temperatures are from 14–15 °C (57–59 °F) in the Carpathians to 16–17 °C (61–63 °F) in Roztocze and 19 °C (66 °F) in the lower part of the Dniester valley. The average annual precipitation is 600–650 mm (23.62–25.59 in) in the lowlands
column2: 650–750 mm (25.59–29.53 in) in the highlands and up to 1
column4: with the majority of precipitation occurring in summer. Prolonged droughts are uncommon
column5: while strong rainfalls can cause floods in river valleys. Severe winds during storms can also cause damage
column6: especially in the highlands. The climate is favourable for the cultivation of sugar beets
column12: and for dairy farming. It is still too cold to successfully cultivate maize
column16: watermelon or peaches in Lviv Oblast. In the Carpathians conditions are favourable for Alpine skiing 3–4 months a year.

column1: Fifty-nine percent of the religious organisations active in the Lviv Oblast adhere to the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church. The Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church is the second largest religious body. The followers of the Roman Catholic Church and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) are mostly from the Polish
column2: and Russian or non-Galician Ukrainian minorities respectively.

column1: The city of Lviv contains a well-preserved main square (Rynok) and numerous historical and beautiful churches. Other sites of interest are the historic Lychakivskiy Cemetery
column3: and the ruins of the famous Vysokyi Zamok. The name of the castle is closely tied to the name of the city. There is also a museum of military artifacts

and monasteries can be found throughout the Oblast. One of them is the Olesko Castle which is first recorded in 1327. Another castle that was built at the end of the 15th century is Svirzh Castle in the village of Svirzh
column4: Peremeshliany Raion. One more and no less famous castle is the Pidhirtsi Castle. Its architectural complex consists of the three-story palace
column6: and small park. In Roztochia is also located the Krekhivsky monastery in the buch-pine grove at the foot of the Pobiyna mount. The whole complex consists of the Saint Nikola Church
column9: and defensive walls with towers. Another site worth of mentioning is the Tustan city-fortress which is built in the rock. The site was nominated as the historical and as the natural wonder of Ukraine. There also a nature complex in the valley of the Kamianka river in Skoliv Raion. Another natural wonder of the region is the Kamin-Veleten (Rock-Giant in English) which is located near city of Pidkamin in Brodivskyi Raion. The name of the local city means Under the Rock. A local museum of Ukrainian art and an institution of higher learning (Ivan Franko State University) are also present.

column1: Most of Ukraine's oblasts are named after their capital cities
column2: officially referred to as "oblast centers" (Ukrainian: обласний центр
column3: translit. oblasnyi tsentr). The name of each oblast is a relative adjective
column4: formed by adding a feminine suffix to the name of respective center city: L'viv is the center of the L'vivs'ka oblast' (Lviv Oblast). Most oblasts are also sometimes referred to in a feminine noun form
column5: following the convention of traditional regional place names
column7: as is the case with the Lviv Oblast
